title: Cinema shut down after police receive ‘credible threat’ linked to new Joker movie
text:
A California movie theatre shut down after receiving a ‘credible’ threat linked to the new ‘Joker’ film. Picture: Huntington Beach Police Department/ DC Comics.

A California movie theatre was forced to shut down and cancel screenings of the controversial new Joker film after police received a ‘credible’ threat linked to its release.

Police were sent to the Century Theatre at the Bella Terra shopping centre in Huntington Beach to deal with the scare on Thursday night.

According to CBS LA, the cinema cancelled all scheduled screenings after 5pm before closing up two hours later.

In a Facebook post Huntington Beach Police Department said it received reports of a possible threat and were treating it as ‘credible’.

Huntington Beach Police Department responded to the threat. Picture: Huntington Beach Police Department.

Joker, which stars Joaquin Phoenix as Batman’s twisted nemesis, has been criticised for its portrayal of violence and there have been heightened security fears surrounding its release.

Police in cities across the US, including New York and Las Vegas, have stepped up patrols at cinemas showing the film

Huntington Beach Police Department declined to provide specific details of the threat but did confirm the California cinema reopened on Friday with the police force carrying out regular patrols at the site for the remainder of the weekend.

The DC Comics villain has become associated with real life tragedy after the 2012 Aurora mass shooting at a movie theatre in Colorado.

During a screening of ‘The Dark Knight Rises’ James Holmes, who reportedly identified himself as Joker, killed 12 people and injured more than 70.

The portrayal of violence in the film has sparked some controversy. Picture: DC Comics

Families of the victims previously voiced concerns about the new film and due to this, it will not be shown at the Aurora multiplex where the shooting took place.

Joker is directed by Todd Phillips and acts as an origins story for Joker. Set in 1981, it follows failed stand-up comedian Arthur Fleck, who turns to a life of crime in Gotham City.

Warner Bros, the studio behind the film, has defended it, saying ‘neither the fictional character Joker, nor the film, is an endorsement of real-world violence of any kind’.
description: A California movie theatre was forced to shut down and cancel screenings of the controversial new Joker film after police received a ‘credible’ threat linked to its release.
